Kenneth Stanley wrote:

>
>Colin, this sounds like a really interesting idea.  I need to think 
>about it also.  I like the idea of keeping away from places that 
>already got stuck.  
>
>  
>
Regarding this point:

>The problem is how do we ensure we generate new genomes 
>  
>
>that are sufficiently different enough from the dead species to go and 
>explore new areas of the search space? 
>
If we solve this problem then we might not have to explicitly avoid 
specific points in the fitness space, since the new genomes hopefully 
have enough distance from the local peaks to not get trapped again.

One other thought, if you avoid specific points/areas then you may still 
end up with a bunch of genomes around the edge of these points/areas if 
they were previously on a climb to a peak, because you still have the 
peak in the fitness space but you prevent genomes from approaching it. 
It's like a ring fence around the peak and as such is not necessarily 
much better than just the peak - unless you perhaps gradually increase 
the areas of the ring fence, by e.g. increasing the compatibility 
threshold with the dead species that define the areas.

Colin.
